trans-unit.source: When your web applications and services handle authentication with <token>firstref_acs</token>, the client must obtain a security token issued by <token>secondref_acs</token> to log in to your application or service.
trans-unit.target: When your web applications and services handle authentication with <token>firstref_acs</token>, the client must obtain a security token issued by <token>secondref_acs</token> to log in to your application or service.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> can issue security tokens in the following formats:
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> can issue security tokens in the following formats:

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> can issue security tokens in any of the following formats.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> can issue security tokens in any of the following formats.

trans-unit.source: The token format that <token>secondref_acs</token> uses for a web application or service is determined by the relying party application configuration.
trans-unit.target: The token format that <token>secondref_acs</token> uses for a web application or service is determined by the relying party application configuration.

trans-unit.source: For information about configuring relying party applications, see <link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Relying Party Applications</link>.
trans-unit.target: For information about configuring relying party applications, see <link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Relying Party Applications</link>.

trans-unit.source: Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) is the oldest and the most common format of tokens in use today for single sign-on (SSO) and claims-based identity.
trans-unit.target: Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) is the oldest and the most common format of tokens in use today for single sign-on (SSO) and claims-based identity.

trans-unit.source: SAML specifies an XML format, for tokens as well as protocols, for performing a web application or a web service SSO using SAML tokens.
trans-unit.target: SAML specifies an XML format, for tokens as well as protocols, for performing a web application or a web service SSO using SAML tokens.

trans-unit.source: For more information about SAML tokens, see <externalLink><linkText>SAML Specifications</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=213719</linkUri></externalLink> (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=213719).
trans-unit.target: For more information about SAML tokens, see <externalLink><linkText>SAML Specifications</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=213719</linkUri></externalLink> (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=213719).

trans-unit.source: SAML 1.1 and SAML 2.0 tokens are widely supported by a number of development platforms, including <externalLink><linkText>Windows Identity Foundation</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=213729</linkUri></externalLink> (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=213729).
trans-unit.target: SAML 1.1 and SAML 2.0 tokens are widely supported by a number of development platforms, including <externalLink><linkText>Windows Identity Foundation</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=213729</linkUri></externalLink> (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=213729).

trans-unit.source: The following is an example of a SAML token.
trans-unit.target: The following is an example of a SAML token.

trans-unit.source: Simple Web Token (SWT) tokens comply with the SimpleWebToken specification.
trans-unit.target: Simple Web Token (SWT) tokens comply with the SimpleWebToken specification.

trans-unit.source: SWT tokens are expressed as form-encoded key/value pairs signed with a cryptographic key.
trans-unit.target: SWT tokens are expressed as form-encoded key/value pairs signed with a cryptographic key.

trans-unit.source: The specification mandates the presence of some key/value pairs, but it leaves room for application-specific key/value pairs.
trans-unit.target: The specification mandates the presence of some key/value pairs, but it leaves room for application-specific key/value pairs.

trans-unit.source: The keys that are always present in an <token>secondref_acs</token>-issued SWT token are shown in the following table.
trans-unit.target: The keys that are always present in an <token>secondref_acs</token>-issued SWT token are shown in the following table.

trans-unit.source: A representation of the <token>secondref_acs</token> <token>servicensd</token> that issued the token.
trans-unit.target: A representation of the <token>secondref_acs</token> <token>servicensd</token> that issued the token.

trans-unit.source: The pattern for this value is https://<servicenamespace>.accesscontrol.windows.net/.
trans-unit.target: The pattern for this value is https://<servicenamespace>.accesscontrol.windows.net/.

trans-unit.source: The value of the <codeInline>applies_to</codeInline> used to request the token.
trans-unit.target: The value of the <codeInline>applies_to</codeInline> used to request the token.

trans-unit.source: This value is either an HTTP or HTTPS URI.
trans-unit.target: This value is either an HTTP or HTTPS URI.

trans-unit.source: The Epoch time upon which the token expires.
trans-unit.target: The Epoch time upon which the token expires.

trans-unit.source: The HMACSHA256 signature of all the other key/value pairs.
trans-unit.target: The HMACSHA256 signature of all the other key/value pairs.

trans-unit.source: This key/value pair is always the last key/value pair in the token.
trans-unit.target: This key/value pair is always the last key/value pair in the token.

trans-unit.source: The form-encoded representation of the other key/value pairs (including application-specific claims) is signed.
trans-unit.target: The form-encoded representation of the other key/value pairs (including application-specific claims) is signed.

trans-unit.source: In addition to these key/value pairs, <token>secondref_acs</token> adds one or more claims to a token before issuance.
trans-unit.target: In addition to these key/value pairs, <token>secondref_acs</token> adds one or more claims to a token before issuance.

trans-unit.source: These claims are driven by the rule configuration present in <token>secondref_acs</token> at the time of the token request.
trans-unit.target: These claims are driven by the rule configuration present in <token>secondref_acs</token> at the time of the token request.

trans-unit.source: All such claims have a type and one or more values, where both the type and the values are strings.
trans-unit.target: All such claims have a type and one or more values, where both the type and the values are strings.

trans-unit.source: When a claim contains more than one value, the values are separated by the comma (“,”) character.
trans-unit.target: When a claim contains more than one value, the values are separated by the comma (“,”) character.

trans-unit.source: Claims are encoded as key/value pairs, exactly as the key/value pairs described in the previous table.
trans-unit.target: Claims are encoded as key/value pairs, exactly as the key/value pairs described in the previous table.

trans-unit.source: The following is an example of an <token>secondref_acs</token> token that contains claims represented as key/value pairs.
trans-unit.target: The following is an example of an <token>secondref_acs</token> token that contains claims represented as key/value pairs.

trans-unit.source: With the exception of the HMACSHA256 key/value pair, these pairs can be in any order.
trans-unit.target: With the exception of the HMACSHA256 key/value pair, these pairs can be in any order.

trans-unit.source: The following <token>secondref_acs</token> token is equivalent to the previous <token>secondref_acs</token> token except for the signatures that are different.
trans-unit.target: The following <token>secondref_acs</token> token is equivalent to the previous <token>secondref_acs</token> token except for the signatures that are different.

trans-unit.source: The following table shows the contents of the token with URL decoded values.
trans-unit.target: The following table shows the contents of the token with URL decoded values.

trans-unit.source: JSON Web token (JWT) support is being added in beta, this means that there can be breaking changes without notice.
trans-unit.target: JSON Web token (JWT) support is being added in beta, this means that there can be breaking changes without notice.

trans-unit.source: The <token>secondref_acs</token> implementation of the JWT token format follows the draft 9 of the JWT specification.
trans-unit.target: The <token>secondref_acs</token> implementation of the JWT token format follows the draft 9 of the JWT specification.

trans-unit.source: Similar to SWT tokens, JWT is a compact token format that is suited for REST web services.
trans-unit.target: Similar to SWT tokens, JWT is a compact token format that is suited for REST web services.

trans-unit.source: Unlike the SWT format, JWT supports a variety of signing options.
trans-unit.target: Unlike the SWT format, JWT supports a variety of signing options.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> supports both symmetric and asymmetric signatures for JWT tokens.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> supports both symmetric and asymmetric signatures for JWT tokens.

trans-unit.source: The claims that are always present in <token>secondref_acs</token>-issued JWT tokens are shown in the following table.
trans-unit.target: The claims that are always present in <token>secondref_acs</token>-issued JWT tokens are shown in the following table.

trans-unit.source: A representation of the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> that issued the token.
trans-unit.target: A representation of the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> that issued the token.

trans-unit.source: The pattern for this value is https://<namespace>.accesscontrol.windows.net/
trans-unit.target: The pattern for this value is https://<namespace>.accesscontrol.windows.net/

trans-unit.source: The value of the scope used to request the token.
trans-unit.target: The value of the scope used to request the token.

trans-unit.source: This value is used to identify the intended recipient of the token.
trans-unit.target: This value is used to identify the intended recipient of the token.

trans-unit.source: The Epoch time before which the token is not valid.
trans-unit.target: The Epoch time before which the token is not valid.

trans-unit.source: The Epoch time upon which the token expires.
trans-unit.target: The Epoch time upon which the token expires.

trans-unit.source: The following algorithms are supported for JWT tokens:
trans-unit.target: The following algorithms are supported for JWT tokens:

trans-unit.source: For signing JWT with a symmetric key .
trans-unit.target: For signing JWT with a symmetric key .

trans-unit.source: For signing JWT an asymmetric key, using an x509 with certificate.
trans-unit.target: For signing JWT an asymmetric key, using an x509 with certificate.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example of a JWT token:
trans-unit.target: Here is an example of a JWT token:

trans-unit.source: JWT is composed of segments, which are delimited using ‘.’.
trans-unit.target: JWT is composed of segments, which are delimited using ‘.’.

trans-unit.source: The following table shows the decoded segments of a JWT token:
trans-unit.target: The following table shows the decoded segments of a JWT token:

trans-unit.source: A single claim with multiple values is represented as a JSON array.
trans-unit.target: A single claim with multiple values is represented as a JSON array.

trans-unit.source: For example if a user is a member of multiple roles, the role claim would appear as follows:
trans-unit.target: For example if a user is a member of multiple roles, the role claim would appear as follows:

trans-unit.source: When a SAML 2.0, SAML 1.1, SWT, JWT token is issued, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses various standard protocols to return the token to a web application or service.
trans-unit.target: When a SAML 2.0, SAML 1.1, SWT, JWT token is issued, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses various standard protocols to return the token to a web application or service.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> supports the following token format/protocol combinations:
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> supports the following token format/protocol combinations:

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> can issue and return SAML 2.0 tokens over the WS-Trust and WS-Federation protocols (depending on the protocol used in the token request).
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> can issue and return SAML 2.0 tokens over the WS-Trust and WS-Federation protocols (depending on the protocol used in the token request).

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> can issue and return SAML 1.1 tokens over the WS-Federation and the related WS-Trust protocols (depending on the protocol used in the token request).
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> can issue and return SAML 1.1 tokens over the WS-Federation and the related WS-Trust protocols (depending on the protocol used in the token request).

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> can issue and return SWT tokens over the WS-Federation, WS-Trust, and OAuth WRAP or OAuth 2.0 protocols, (depending on the protocol used in the token request).
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> can issue and return SWT tokens over the WS-Federation, WS-Trust, and OAuth WRAP or OAuth 2.0 protocols, (depending on the protocol used in the token request).

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> can issue JWT tokens over the WS-Federation, WS-Trust, and or OAuth 2.0 protocols, (depending on the protocol used in the token request).
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> can issue JWT tokens over the WS-Federation, WS-Trust, and or OAuth 2.0 protocols, (depending on the protocol used in the token request).
